full_bio.p: Anne de Marcken is an interdisciplinary writer and artist. Credits include poetry, short stories, short and feature-length films, web environments, and site-specific installations. Her writing has been featured on NPR’s Selected Shorts and in such publications as Best New American Voices, Glimmer Train, and Southern Indiana Review. She has received numerous awards for her writing and film work and been supported by grants and fellowships from Jentel Foundation, Centrum and Artist Trust.

faculty.title: Faculty

full_bio.p: Douglas Hammel, M.B.A. is the principal Business Development Specialist with Douglas Hammel & Associates (www.douglashammel.com.) He was previously the Director of the Small Business Development Center (SBDC) located in Olympia, Washington. His duties include one-on-one counseling/consulting with a wide variety of businesses, and presentation of business workshops.

He has developed a unique and highly effective method for business development that will be presented in his forthcoming book "Succeed Entrepreneur Succeed!: Your Essential Problem Solving Guide." He has consulted successfully with over three thousand clients since 1991.

faculty.title: Faculty

full_bio.p: DK is an expert in Personal and Organizational Leadership Development, Human Dynamics, and Executive Coaching. He has over twenty years of innovative management and leadership experience in the private and public sectors and played leadership roles at Intel Corporation, a Fortune 500 Corp. He served as the Deputy and Interim Executive Director of the Washington State Human Rights Commission, Chief HR, IS, and Strategic Planning for the Department of Veterans Affairs, and Director of Operations for the DSHS Economic Services Administration in Washington State. In 2007, DK was honored with the Washington State Prestigious Governor’s Leadership Award.

faculty.name: Withey, John
faculty.interest: landscape ecology, conservation biology, avian ecology, native wildlife response to land use and climate change, empirical field studies, ecological modeling, GIS.
faculty.bio: B.A., Biology, Pomona College, 1991; M.S., Wildlife Science, University of Washington, 2002; Ph.D., Forest Resources, University of Washington, 2006.
faculty.title: Faculty
faculty.full_bio: John is a terrestrial ecologist who studies the responses of native wildlife (especially birds!) to urbanization and climate change. He uses a combination of empirical field studies, modeling and quantitative tools, and spatial analyses using GIS in his work. Since receiving his Ph.D. in 2006 he has taught and conducted research at the University of Washington (Seattle), Lewis & Clark College (Portland), the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (Panama), and Florida International University (Miami).
